name: Comprehensive Desktop and Window Manager Features
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide range of desktop environments, window managers, related applications, and supplementary tools. It provides a modular and flexible framework to support various user preferences, system specifications, and use cases. The feature includes support for modern desktop environments like GNOME, KDE, Budgie, Cinnamon, Deepin, MATE, LXDE, LXQt, Xfce, as well as traditional and tiling window managers such as Sway, XMonad, and i3. Additionally, it integrates accessibility tools, productivity suites, software development environments, multimedia, games, and compatibility layers, enabling a fully functional and customizable graphical user interface across diverse platforms.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop
Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Comprehensive System Management and Development Suite
description: A unified parent feature encompassing a wide range of tools, utilities, and frameworks designed to manage, develop, and optimize systems of varying scales. This suite integrates system administration tools, hardware monitoring, graphical utilities, database management, scientific applications, security frameworks, and performance debugging utilities. It is tailored for administrators, developers, and engineers working in diverse computing environments, such as desktop systems, large-scale servers, networking, and scientific simulations.

name: Linux Development and Software Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive set of tools, libraries, platforms, environments, and utilities designed to support software development, compatibility, authoring, technical writing, educational pursuits, and legacy systems. This parent feature encompasses capabilities for developing applications using various programming languages, frameworks, and platforms, as well as tools for creative, technical, and collaborative workflows. It further includes compatibility for older systems, input methods for internationalization, and resources for learning and teaching. This ecosystem offers the essential components for both basic Linux usage and advanced application development, addressing diverse developer and user needs.

name: Linux Cloud and Virtualization Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive feature set encompassing all tools, software, and utilities required for modern cloud computing, container management, virtualization platforms, and infrastructure support. This feature group provides a unified approach to managing and operating in cloud-based, virtualized, and containerized environments, including tools for system provisioning, server management, desktop agents for virtualization, platform-specific drivers, and remote management utilities. It enables end-to-end solutions tailored for cloud infrastructure, virtualization technologies (KVM, VMware, Hyper-v), container ecosystems, and graphical creation tools for cloud and virtual machine environments.

name: Infrastructure and Service Management
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide variety of tools, services, and software components aimed at managing, hosting, and supporting infrastructure environments and network-based services. It includes software for print and file management, identity and directory solutions, network traffic management, high-availability configurations, and tools for legacy and modern communication protocols. Moreover, it covers server capabilities such as email, web, DNS, FTP, and news hosting, as well as specialized applications like 3D printing, load balancing, and grid computing. This feature also integrates client and server functionality for backup, directory services, smart card authentication, and storage solutions, ensuring robust support for both legacy and cutting-edge enterprise requirements.

name: Linux Product Model Core and Support Features
description: A comprehensive parent feature encompassing all core functionalities, critical dependencies, and modular support configurations necessary for various Linux product variants, application environments, and specialized package setups. This parent feature ensures consistency, modularity, and conflict resolution across different use cases and system configurations. The sub-features covered extend core installation capabilities, critical paths for functional subsystems, variant-specific requirements, and additional application suites.
